title: How to Get Away With Manslaughter
summary: The Supreme Court's McGirt ruling opened a bizarre loophole for Oklahoma criminals.. Shaynna Sims was haunted by the fact that her husband had been having an affair. So when his lover died in 2015, Ms. Sims went to a viewing at the Tulsa, Okla., funeral home. There she mutilated the woman's body, which prosecutors later said had both breasts "crudely cut off." She also took graphic pictures, including one with her wedding ring "prominently displayed." Ms. Sims received 16 years in prison in 2017, but last month she was freed.

title: Build Back Better vs. Small Business
summary: Wage mandates for green subsidies will squeeze nonunion shops.. We've been telling you about special political favors hidden throughout the Democratic spending bill-subsidies for the press corps, the trial bar and green energy. But the biggest single winner may be Big Labor, and one egregious example is the wage mandate for contractors that would lock out small business.

title: November's Jobs Message to the Federal Reserve
summary: The labor market is healthy enough to take higher interest rates.. Friday's jobs report for November was stronger than Republicans and many in the media are saying. While the U.S. added fewer jobs than expected, the labor force swelled with new workers. What do you know? More Americans are looking for work now that the pandemic enhanced unemployment benefits have lapsed.

title: Seattle Defunds the Police Again
summary: Voters have rejected lawlessness, but the City Council isn't listening.. Some politicians are getting the message that crime doesn't pay politically, with Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf this week seeking to hire more police. "There's nothing progressive about unbridled gun violence," the mayor said. Then there's Seattle, where the incorrigible City Council has voted to defund the police for the second year in a row.

title: The Vast Promise of mRNA Technology
summary: The Covid vaccine platform offers real hope for treating many other diseases, including cancer. How an immigrant from Hungary played a prominent scientific role.. Are Covid-19 vaccines a failure? That's the view in some media quarters amid breakthrough infections and new virus variants. It's also false. Vaccinated people are more prone to mild infections than public-health authorities initially anticipated. But the shots continue to provide strong protection against serious disease, and the mRNA vaccines in particular-Pfizer/BioNTech's and Moderna's-are adaptable to new variants.

title: Yes, Justice Sotomayor, the Court Will 'Survive'
summary: The abortion case is about life and liberty, not her and her colleagues.. According to Justice Sonia Sotomayor, it is not only, perhaps not even primarily, the right of a woman to control her own body, or the right of a developing human being to life, that is in question in the outcome of the Supreme Court's decision on a Mississippi law that bans most abortions after 15 weeks. At stake is the reputation-no, the very survival-of the Supreme Court.

title: Alec Baldwin Says Fatal 'Rust' Shooting Occurred After He Let Go of Gun's Hammer
summary: Actor says in ABC interview that he didn't know there was a live round in the gun and isn't to blame for the tragedy. Actor Alec Baldwin said the gunshot that killed a cinematographer on the set of Western film "Rust" occurred after he pulled back the gun's hammer and let it go.

title: What Spreads Faster Than Covid? Vaccination.
summary: Our last pointless ideological fight may be over whether the vaccinated are spreaders.. It deserves a wow. Some 57% of the human population has received at least one dose of the Covid-19 vaccine, and 45% are fully vaccinated, in less than a year.

title: Hawaii Is No Paradise if You Need Medical Care
summary: High taxes contribute to a shortage of doctors while certificate-of-need laws crimp capacity.. Honolulu

title: Notable & Quotable: Stacey Abrams Says 'I Did Not Challenge' the Election
summary: 'When I acknowledged I would not become governor, that he had won the election, I did not challenge the outcome of the election.'. MSNBC's Rachel Maddow interviewing Stacey Abrams, Dec. 2. Ms. Abrams, a Democrat, lost the Georgia governor's race in 2018 and announced Wednesday she'll run again in 2022:

title: A Young Boy Found Older Brothers in the Beatles
summary: Joe Peppercorn turned his gratitude for the band into an annual marathon of their music.. Once in a while, when the stars are aligned just right in the night sky, life can become a beautiful song.

title: Didi Hunts for Way to Delist, Rocking Chinese ADRs
summary: Ride-hailing company has asked investment banks for proposals on how Hong Kong listing, New York delisting might work. Investors punished shares of Chinese companies traded in the U.S. on Friday as Didi Global Inc. searched for ways to back out of its New York stock listing months after the initial public offering drew Beijing's ire.

title: Apple Notified State Department Workers That Phones Were Hacked
summary: Foreign service officers in Uganda among those informed their iPhones were compromised in attack. Apple Inc. last week notified 11 U.S. State Department employees in Uganda that their iPhones were hacked, and investigators have linked the attack to a tool developed by NSO Group, an Israeli technology company that was blacklisted by the Biden administration, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Tech Stocks, Omicron Concerns Pull Stock Markets Down
summary: All three major indexes declined Friday; investors consider fresh worries that have spurred volatility. Markets ended a tumultuous week on an ominous note, with a broad technology-sector selloff sending major U.S. stock indexes sharply lower and Treasury yields falling at a pace not seen since some of the worst days of the pandemic last year.

title: A Commute for All Generations
summary: Walt Whitman's 'Crossing Brooklyn Ferry' takes a simple boat ride and imbues it with timelessness.

title: Retailers Bolster Security After 'Flash Mob' Robberies
summary: Retailers lock up more products and California police increase patrols to combat thefts by criminal groups. Retailers and law enforcement around the country are ramping up security to combat a wave of thefts by criminal groups during the busy holiday shopping season.

title: Fly Me to the Swamp
summary: Washington is the hot destination for 'protest tourism.'. President Joe Biden's latest Covid rules are bound to discourage international travel, so the timing could be perfect for a popular domestic destination to attract even more visitors. Washington, D.C. isn't just for school field trips and trade association meetings any more. Now it's the undisputed mecca of unhappy vacationers!

title: Ill-Advised (Saturday Crossword, December 4)
U.S. to Urge Democracies to Sanction Corrupt Foreign Officials, Human-Rights Abusers
summary: Biden administration will unveil sanctions in run-up to Summit for Democracy. WASHINGTON-The U.S. next week will levy sanctions against foreign-government officials and people it accuses of corruption and human-rights abuse, and urge other nations to join its pressure campaign at its coming Summit for Democracy, administration officials said.

title: Lilly's Covid-19 Antibody Treatment Authorized for Use in Children
summary: The FDA's authorization expands the drug's use to fight Covid-19 to people under the age of 12. Eli Lilly & Co.'s monoclonal antibody drug has been cleared for emergency use in children under the age of 12, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday.

title: DocuSign Shares Fall More Than 40% as Customer Behavior Shifts
summary: The e-signature software company's CEO says the company didn't react swiftly enough to changing trends. DocuSign Inc.'s shares sank 42% on Friday after the company warned that consumers were returning to more normalized buying patterns with the widespread rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and the gradual return to the workplace.

title: Twitter CEO Shakes Up Leadership Team to Spur Change
summary: Moves quickly follow departure of Jack Dorsey late last month. Twitter Inc.'s newly appointed chief executive, Parag Agrawal, is shaking up the company's leadership team less than a week into the job in a bid to quickly spur changes.

title: Michael Smerconish to Fill In for Chris Cuomo on CNN
summary: Cuomo was suspended after details emerged of his efforts to help his brother, former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, respond to sexual-misconduct allegations. CNN anchor Michael Smerconish will temporarily fill in for Chris Cuomo next week, the cable network said.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Slide After Jobs Data
summary: Yields touch multimonth lows amid concerns about tighter Fed policy, Omicron variant. Investors drove yields on U.S. government bonds to multimonth lows Friday, with worries about tighter monetary policy and the Omicron variant weighing on expectations for economic growth.

title: Cathie Wood's ARK Innovation ETF Sinks During Selloff
summary: The popular exchange-traded fund fell 6% Friday, as technology stocks staged a sharp pullback. A broad selloff in technology shares is punishing fund manager Cathie Wood's flagship ARK Innovation exchange-traded fund.

title: White House Readies Plan to Boost Cybersecurity of Water Supply
summary: Utilities are reviewing a proposal to help detect hacks and share data with authorities. The Biden administration is readying a proposal to shore up the cybersecurity of the U.S. water supply, a system maintained by thousands of organizations with sometimes glaring vulnerabilities to hackers.

title: Wages Shoot Up in Travel, Food and Other In-Demand Industries
summary: November jobs report also offers early signals that wage growth may be easing. U.S. wages continue to rise at a brisk pace in November, particularly in sectors with the most acute labor shortages, Friday's jobs report showed.

title: Oil Prices Recover Some Losses After Omicron Drove Demand Fears
summary: U.S. crude finished week above lows as Brent rose Friday. Oil prices showed signs of recovery after worries about the economic effect of the spreading Omicron variant of Covid-19 drove crude into a bear market.

title: Former Unilever CIO Moves Into Health Care
summary: Jane Moran looks to bring a consumer focus to health system Mass General Brigham as its first chief information and digital officer. Jane Moran, a former global chief information officer at Unilever PLC, is working to improve technology at a Boston-based health system, including by enhancing the hospital experience for patients and their families.

title: France to Sell Jet Fighters to U.A.E.
summary: United Arab Emirates' deal for American military aircraft has been held up over the country's cooperation with Beijing. France agreed to sell $19 billion of military aircraft to the United Arab Emirates, including jet fighters, while the U.S. Gulf ally's burgeoning security ties with China impede its purchase of advanced American combat jets.

title: Iran Nuclear Talks Stall as Tehran Toughens Stance
summary: Western diplomats say Iran must moderate demands in discussions that are set to resume next week. Talks to revive the Iran nuclear deal stalled on Friday, with Western allies warning the effort was a step closer to collapse after Tehran's negotiators barely inched from their stance over a week of negotiations.

title: Why Instagram Asks Users to Create Second Accounts
summary: An in-app notice calls on users to 'try a new account.' Can a fresh start keep people from losing their enthusiasm for the platform?. Instagram has quietly rolled out a pop-up over the past year that encourages users to "try a new account." The notice says it will help people "keep up with a smaller group of friends" and explore their interests more easily.

title: Justice Department Argues It Should Defend Trump in Defamation Suit
summary: Suit was brought by E. Jean Carroll, who said former president raped her in the 1990s. A Justice Department lawyer argued Friday that the U.S. should be permitted to represent Donald Trump in a defamation lawsuit filed by the columnist E. Jean Carroll, saying the law protects a president from being sued in such a case.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: Picasso's 'Minotaur' period, artists on trial, pandemic fiction and our list of the 10 Best Books of 2021..

title: Gains in Workforce Point to Loosening of Labor Market
summary: Unemployment rate falls to 4.2%; recovery faces new Covid-19 uncertainties. Hiring slowed last month amid Covid-19 uncertainties, but people returned to the labor force in droves in a sign the tight labor market could be loosening.

title: The Law of Abortion and the Court of Public Opinion
summary: The left fears losing the myth that a fetus is merely a clump of cells more than a court decision it can overturn later.. I agree with your principal argument that the Constitution is silent on abortion and therefore its regulation is best left to the states ("An Abortion Crossroads," Review & Outlook, Dec. 1). Most legal minds, on both sides of the debate, agree that the constitutional basis for Roe v. Wade (1973) is questionable at best.

title: Why Am I Being Blamed for Covid Lockdowns?
summary: Older voters like me did not support draconian policies that burden our kids and grandkids.. As one of those "older voters" Holman W. Jenkins, Jr. refers to in "Is This a 'Normal' Covid Winter?" (Business World, Nov. 27), I take issue with his depiction of us as "terrified" of the virus and "unstinting in our willingness to impose costs on young people for steps that lack any real benefit." As if it weren't enough that, in our golden years we were forced into lives of seclusion, locked in nursing and retirement homes with meals delivered to our doors, and told we must settle for visits with kids and grandkids through closed windows for our own good, now Mr. Jenkins implies that we were behind these measures.

title: Jane Austen Lost Him. History Did Not.
summary: Tom Lefroy had an interesting life after the romance.. It was edifying to read Colleen Sheehan's "Breaking News From 1795: Jane Austen Falls in Love" (Nov. 26). Yet the op-ed left one thinking that Tom Lefroy, Austen's suspected love, was simply a callow upper-class youth lost to history after his dalliance with Austen. Not so. Thomas Langlois Lefroy (1776-1869) was a noted Irish barrister and a member of the British Parliament. He was appointed to the Privy Council for Ireland and presided for 14 years as Lord Chief Justice of Ireland. Austen's niece, Anna Austen, married Benjamin Lefroy. Their daughter married Justice Lefroy's nephew, also named Tom. It is through these connections that much proof of the romance between Jane Austen and Tom Lefroy comes down to us today.

title: When Dogs Become Replacement Children
summary: Add another form of social dysfunction to Peggy Noonan's list.. Peggy Noonan's "Social Distancing Was a Problem Before Covid" (Declarations, Nov. 27) brings to light much about concerning trends in marriage, child rearing and socialization. One related point, however, was left out: The female instinct to nurture has not disappeared-it has been transferred in many cases from children to dogs.

title: Declining Jobless Rate Keeps Fed on Track to Accelerate Taper
summary: Unemployment is falling faster than Fed officials have anticipated. Another decline in the unemployment rate in November keeps the Federal Reserve on track to quicken the wind-down of its stimulus programs at its meeting later this month, paving the way to raise interest rates in the first half of next year to curb inflation.

title: Did Anyone at Wuhan Ask What Could Go Wrong?
summary: Open-minded exploration of risk is too often absent in science and engineering.. Regarding Adam O'Neal's review "What Happened in Wuhan?" (Books, Nov. 27): The most astounding thing I've learned in engineering and science-hundreds of hands-on projects, leading companies, university teaching, writing about technical subjects-is that open-minded exploration of what could go wrong is so rarely practiced before embarking on programs affecting health and safety, and that the most highly educated and experienced are the least likely to entertain such an exploration.

title: Stop the Spread of Federal Agencies
summary: Voters with an interest in growing Washington do enough damage in the D.C. area.. Regarding Faith Bottum's "When Federal Employees Telecommute, Why Are Agencies in D.C.?" (op-ed, Nov. 27): Moving federal employees out of the Washington area is a bad idea. If federal employees were further spread around the union, their political power base would expand. They would be directly represented by more members of Congress, and if you review voting behavior in D.C. and surrounding counties, it is overwhelmingly supportive of Democrats and progressive politics. These voters have an interest in larger government. Far better to keep federal employees in the Washington area and simply reduce their numbers.

title: Gunmakers Not Liable in 2017 Las Vegas Shooting, Judges Say
summary: Nevada Supreme Court rules state law grants companies immunity from wrongful death and negligence claims. The Nevada Supreme Court ruled gun manufacturers and distributors couldn't be held responsible for the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history because of existing state law.

title: Omicron Cases at Norway Christmas Party Provide Clues on New Variant's Spread
summary: It spread among fully vaccinated people, but symptoms among those infected so far appear mild. An Omicron outbreak at a Norwegian Christmas party is providing an early, if still anecdotal, data point on the ease through which the new variant spreads between vaccinated people, and how mild its symptoms at times can be.

title: Designing for a Pandemic
summary: A new exhibition shows how artists and engineers rose to the challenge of Covid-19. Two years ago, members of the nonprofit MASS Design Group and Ellen Lupton, a senior curator at the New York design museum Cooper Hewitt, began to plan an exhibition on design and healthcare. Then the Covid-19 pandemic put New York City in lockdown, and suddenly the proposed show had a new urgency and focus.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Demand Strains CVS, Walgreens
summary: Pharmacies recommend booking appointments as concerns over Omicron variant push people to seek shots. The U.S. has plenty of Covid-19 vaccines but retail pharmacies are struggling to quickly administer them in some places.

title: Chinese Sponsor Distanced Itself From Women's Tennis Before WTA Pulled Events From China
summary: The WTA said that iQiyi, a Netflix-like streaming platform, asked to be removed from the WTA's website as the organization spoke out about Peng Shuai. The Women's Tennis Association said that its largest Chinese sponsor asked last week to be removed from the organization's website, the latest sign of tension between the tour and China after a sexual-assault allegation against a former Chinese government official was made on the verified social-media account of tennis pro Peng Shuai.

title: Omicron's Severity Will Take More Time to Assess, Scientists Say
summary: The Covid-19 variant seems more transmissible and presents higher reinfection risk, South African officials say based on early evidence. JOHANNESBURG-Scientists in South Africa say they are reaching preliminary answers to two of the three big questions about the Omicron coronavirus variant: Is it more contagious than earlier versions, is it more effective at bypassing the body's immune responses and does it make you sicker?

title: Robert Gottlieb Is a 'Crazed Reader' Turned Legendary Editor
summary: The author of a new biography of Greta Garbo helped to shape the work of writers like Toni Morrison, John le Carré and Robert Caro. Greta Garbo once observed that she had never felt like a child. In a new biography of the film star published this week, renowned editor and publisher Robert Gottlieb, 90, suggests that her father's premature death, her family's poverty and her height-she reached 5'7" by the time she was 12 years old-conspired to deprive her of "ever having felt young," as she once said. It's one of the few things Mr. Gottlieb and his subject have in common.

title: While Shell Resists Breakup, Rivals See Opportunity From Spinoffs
summary: Italy's Eni and other European energy conglomerates are spinning off parts of their low-carbon energy assets or considering such moves to boost returns. Royal Dutch Shell PLC is standing firm against Third Point LLC's call for a breakup of the oil giant to retain and attract investors. But that isn't stopping Eni SpA and other European energy conglomerates from targeting similar moves to boost shareholder returns.

title: Holiday Baking: These Cookbooks Are by Far the Season's Friendliest
summary: In two new, highly giftable volumes, baking pros Dorie Greenspan and Vallery Lomas offer more than reliable recipes: They all but step into your kitchen to cook along with you. WE COOK sometimes just to feed ourselves, but when we bake, it's usually for other people. After all, no one can (should?) devour a tray of sea-salt brownies all on her own. And as we trudge into our second pandemic winter, the simple gesture of leaving a batch of cinnamon buns on a doorstep holds even more meaning than usual. Perhaps that's why, for guidance, we gravitate to bakers who aren't just masters of technique but also beacons of warmth.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Selections from 'History of Western Art in Comics', Part 1 and 2 by Marion Augustin, illustration by Bruno Heitz. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Selections from 'A History of Music for Children' by Mary Richards and David Schweitzer, illustrated by Rose Blake. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Public-Service Loan 'Forgiveness': Answers to Common Questions
summary: The rules have changed for a limited period for these student loans. Here is what borrowers should keep in mind.. The federal government's Public Service Loan Forgiveness program, established in 2007, has been riddled with problems and complaints. The complex system has left many student-loan borrowers frustrated and surprised when they discover either that payments they've made don't qualify for forgiveness or that they still have many payments to go before their loan forgiveness kicks in.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Selections from 'The Ultimate Art Museum' by Ferren Gipson. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: China Evergrande Requests Help From Government as Debt Crunch Looms
summary: Working group will oversee and improve company's risk management and internal controls. Chinese authorities on Friday said they would step in to help China Evergrande Group deal with its crisis, after the highly indebted property giant warned it risked defaulting on a large financial obligation and sought help from its provincial government.

title: Embarrassed by Your Spotify Wrapped List? You're Not the Only One.
summary: This year, some users were surprised to see how song choices reflected pandemic coping strategies and melancholy emotional states. David Martin has been feeling restless after almost two years stuck at home. But when the 35-year-old opened his Spotify "Wrapped" roundup on Wednesday, he wasn't expecting to learn he had streamed "Time Stand Still" by Rush dozens of times since last December.

title: Creature Comforts
summary: This 12,000-square-foot house for sale has a fitness center, five fireplaces, a greenhouse and a chef's kitchen.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'A Life of Picasso: The Minotaur Years' Review: So Much Larger Than Life
summary: In the posthumously published conclusion to his multivolume life of Picasso, John Richardson confronts his subject at his most challenging.. "Picasso used to be a great painter," Georges Braque was fond of saying, only partly in jest. "Now he is merely a genius." To remove the tired screens of celebrity and myth that concealed Picasso was the project of the last 40 years of John Richardson's life. Over four volumes, he traced six decades, still more mistresses and movements, and arrived at something like understanding of this complicated, almost unfairly talented figure. Though Richardson's finale, "The Minotaur Years, 1933-1943," was unfinished at his death at 95 in 2019, he doesn't appear, as Thucydides did, to have left the reader midsentence.

title: Colorado Home With Campground Included Hits the Market for $33.5 Million
summary: Near Durango, property on 175 acres has a four-bedroom house plus campsites and RV hookups. In Colorado, a roughly 175-acre property with a campground included is hitting the market for $33.5 million.

title: 'Drawing the Line' Review: Artists on Trial
summary: A philosophy professor offers a guidebook to bringing judgment to the works of the past-and their creators.. Enjoying the novels of Ernest Hemingway can be a difficult thing to do after reading the man's biography. "A Farewell to Arms" and "For Whom the Bell Tolls" are masterpieces of efficient storytelling that changed Anglophone writing forever. But their author was an inveterate liar, prone to hedonism and violence, vicious beyond belief to wives and friends, and culpably stupid on political subjects.

title: Containment Can Work Against China, Too
summary: Resume Subscription. In the defining geopolitical contest of this century, the U.S. is a superpower without a plan. The last two presidents have declared that our country is engaged in a historic competition with China-one that will shape the world order and the fate of human freedom. But neither Donald Trump nor Joe Biden has publicly explained what a more "competitive" policy aims to achieve, nor has either offered more than the barest outlines of a strategy for success. We appear to be embarking on a long, dangerous journey without knowing where we are trying to go or how we will get there.

title: Turkey's Economic Turmoil Sends Desperation and Inflation Soaring
summary: Resume Subscription. ISTANBUL-The two-decade economic boom that lifted millions of Turks into the middle class is beginning to unravel, threatened by a currency crisis that has people lining up for subsidized bread, cutting back on meat and fleeing for a better life in Europe.

title: Jobs Report Gets a Participation Trophy
summary: Drop in unemployment in the face of tepid payrolls growth hints at growing labor-force participation, but it is too early to celebrate. For anybody who was looking for clarity in Friday's jobs report on whether America's labor market is getting a little less tight-well, maybe next year.

title: 'The Struggle for India's Soul' Review: Nationalism in New Delhi
summary: An Indian politician and writer calls for a return to liberal ideals.. If there were a prize for the most eloquent politician in India, Shashi Tharoor would be a favorite to win. His only competition comes from Narendra Modi, the Indian prime minister, who is as silver-tongued in Hindi as Mr. Tharoor is in English. This contest of eloquence is, of course, swaddled in irony, for the well-born and Westernized Mr. Tharoor is among the most outspoken members of the parliamentary opposition to Mr. Modi and his Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party. The two men embody two radically different versions of India.

title: Children's Books: A Museum Visit, With All the Time in the World
summary: Exploring the wonders of the art world and beyond in a choice list of nonfiction gifts for kids.. It's normal to have mixed emotions when visiting a major art collection. There's the uplifting pleasure of finding old favorites and discovering new ones. There may be perplexity at the way some exhibits are curated and exasperation with captions that do not satisfy. And there's the humming anxiety of knowing that you won't have time to see everything. This last feeling is the only one readers will be able to avoid with "The Ultimate Art Museum," a brightly colored, globe-spanning tome by art historian Ferren Gipson that delivers the classic stimulating, yet frustrating, museum experience.

title: Why Investors Are Often Bullish in December
summary: Whatever the reason, one consequence is that a bear market is unlikely to begin in the last few weeks of the year. Chalk it up to the holiday spirit: In December, both professional stock-market timers and individual investors are more bullish than in any other month.

title: China Set to Create New State-Owned Rare-Earths Giant
summary: The move, expected to be announced this month, would aim to strengthen China's dominance of the global supply chain around the strategic metals. China has approved the creation of one of the world's largest rare-earths companies to aim to maintain its dominance in the global supply chain of the strategic metals as tensions deepen with the U.S., according to people familiar with the matter.

title: The Best New Ski Apps to Maximize Your Performance on the Slopes
summary: We tested new schussing softwares-from apps that alert you of icy conditions to ones that give you a 360-degree playback of your day-to see if they live up to the hype. SKI APPS have long offered basic features like trail guides and snow conditions. But the latest tech can help you navigate smarter routes through untouched terrain, alert you of icy conditions on the black-diamond run you're headed toward and provide a 360 degree satellite playback of your day. "Apps have changed everything. As long as your phone works, you know exactly where you are and where you've been," said Tom Bennett, a Jackson, Wyo., ski guide.

title: Fiction: Pandemic Plots
summary: Novels inspired by current events can become stale quickly-but Covid-inspired fiction is nevertheless here.. I will admit that I am a little fearful of the onslaught of Covid-19 fiction heading toward us in the coming years. Novelists have long been preoccupied by the subjects of illness and grief, and they have a disposition, born from lonely experience, for depictions of isolation. The parts are in place for a staggering amount of literary solipsism. How long can it be before every other book has squashed the pandemic into a metaphor for living like secluded, neurasthenic creative artists?

title: Canada Delivers Stellar November Job Gain
summary: Canada adds 153,700 jobs as unemployment rate drops sharply; analysts envisage earlier-than-expected rate rise. OTTAWA-Canada continued its stellar job-creation run in November with another blowout performance that included a sharp drop in the unemployment rate to near pre-pandemic levels.

title: 'Squirrel Hill' Review: A Synagogue Endures Hate
summary: The 2018 attack on the Tree of Life synagogue shocked the nation. Few followed the story of the aftermath.. There have been hundreds of mass shootings in the U.S. and countless books written about them. I hadn't read any of them, nor, thankfully, had I been touched by any of those incidents. That is, until the worst anti-Semitic attack in U.S. history occurred. Mark Oppenheimer's "Squirrel Hill: The Tree of Life Synagogue Shooting and the Soul of a Neighborhood" was written in the aftermath of that attack.

title: How the NFL Ruled Antonio Brown's Vaccine Card Was Forged
summary: The Buccaneers' star was caught using a Covid vaccination card with false information on it. But the investigation was a warning sign for employers everywhere: verifying records can be extremely challenging.. When Tampa Bay Buccaneers wide receiver Antonio Brown was accused by his former chef of procuring a fake Covid-19 vaccine card, it prompted a scramble by the National Football League to answer a seemingly simple question:

title: Mysteries: Michael Connelly's 'The Dark Hours'
summary: A New Year's Eve death begins a search for answers that links two of the author's leading sleuths.. "The Dark Hours," Michael Connelly's latest novel starring LAPD detective Renée Ballard, begins in the final minutes of 2020, a year which, for "most people in the city and the world . . . couldn't end soon enough." But for Ballard, this New Year's Eve presents a chance to catch up with the "Midnight Men," a pair of vicious rapists victimizing L.A. women on holiday nights.

title: 'Around the World in 80 Books' Review: The Ultimate Armchair Traveler
summary: On a Jules Verne-inspired jaunt via great books, who needs an airplane?. As an authority on world literature, Harvard scholar David Damrosch has often traveled abroad to lecture about his work. Last year, Mr. Damrosch was ready to hit the road again-this time with a special project in mind. He'd visit cities that had shaped some of his favorite books, writing about the ways in which place meets story.

title: 'Vivian Maier Developed' Review: Her Private Eye
summary: The second life of a nanny to the wealthy was behind the camera, capturing the ordinary from oblique angles.. In 2007, the art scholar John Maloof was digging through piles of boxes during a foreclosure action in Chicago, looking for potential material for a book. What he found was much more than that-a trove of remarkable photographs, haphazardly labeled and bearing no trace of their owner, save for some processing envelopes with the name "Vivian Maier." Mr. Maloof bought the lot, then contacted every other buyer who had purchased Maier's boxes and bought those, too. All told he amassed 140,000 prints and 45,000 undeveloped negatives.

title: Medical Records Data Offers Doctors Hope of Better Patient Care
summary: Resume Subscription. Author

title: Kearney Executive Expanded Scope of Business Consulting
summary: Marvin Schiller, who has died at age 88, forged longer relationships with companies by increasing services and using performance-based fees. Marvin Schiller parlayed a doctorate in psychology into a career as a top executive at business consulting firm Kearney, where he expanded the advice and services provided to large companies.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach Makes Splashy Return
summary: Art collectors turned out en masse for the season-capping event at the shore. Miami

title: I Miss My New Best Friends, the Beatles
summary: An astonishing-and quite long-documentary breathes warm life into an iconic band. I'm desperate to hang out some more with the Beatles, and I know I'm not alone in feeling this. I miss Paul, John, George and Ringo. I feel like we had such a great Thanksgiving weekend together-them making iconic songs, sipping tea and mildly bickering, and me on the couch, lying in the darkness, microwaved leftovers on my chest.

title: Didi to Delist From U.S., Seek Shift to Hong Kong
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant says it plans to pursue a listing in Hong Kong. Didi Global Inc. plans to delist its shares in the U.S. and pursue a listing in Hong Kong, a dramatic reversal just months after the Chinese ride-hailing group's ill-fated initial public offering in New York.

title: Five Best: Books on Truth and Power
summary: Selected by David A, Andelman, the author, most recently, of 'A Red Line in the Sand: Diplomacy, Strategy, and the History of Wars That Might Still Happen.'. By Barry Gewen (2020)

title: Asia-Pacific Nations Use Tougher Tactics to Combat Omicron Variant
summary: Across the region, governments are changing their playbooks to contain the new variant. Countries in the Asia-Pacific region are creating tougher rules for those infected with the Omicron Covid-19 variant, as governments move more aggressively than they have against all other previous iterations, including Delta.

title: Europe Sees Boost in Uptake of Shots but Mandates Are Still on the Table
summary: Stricter restrictions are driving the unvaccinated to the margins of public life just before the holiday season. Relentless pressure to raise vaccination rates in Europe is beginning to bear fruit as governments make delivering more Covid-19 shots the core of their strategies to slow rising infections, but pockets of resistance to the shots mean some countries are leaning toward general vaccine mandates.

title: Didi Global, Ulta Beauty, Nvidia: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: New York-listed Didi Global shares fall premarket after car maker says it plans to delist in U.S.. U.S. stock futures edged higher, while oil prices rose after OPEC and a group of Russia-led oil producers agreed to continue pumping more crude. The jobs report showed the U.S. added 210,000 jobs in November, fewer than economists expected. Here are the stocks we are tracking before the opening bell.

title: Allianz Strikes Deal Over Management of $35 Billion in U.S. Annuities
summary: German financial giant is one of the top sellers of fixed annuities, a popular retirement product, to individuals in the U.S.. German insurer Allianz SE said its U.S. life insurer had reached an agreement to reinsure liabilities of $35 billion, in one of the largest transactions of its kind.

title: The Splashy Hires at USC and LSU Were a Long Time Coming in College Football
summary: As the pressure and money in college football ratchets up, schools increasingly feel they have no choice but to win now at all costs. Lincoln Riley was only halfway through his introductory news conference as Southern California's new head coach on Monday before he was asked how rapidly he could turn around the Trojans program, which has struggled to a 4-7 record this season after ousting the coach in September.

title: Omicron Variant Puts Companies on Notice This Holiday Season
summary: Some companies are considering canceling holiday gatherings this month, and many are doubling down on vaccine mandates. Concerns about a new Covid-19 variant are prompting some U.S. businesses to double down on vaccine mandates and to rethink hosting holiday festivities this month, while many others are taking a wait-and-see approach as they look to government agencies for more guidance.

title: Biden Struggles to Win Support From Democrats for Vacant Wall Street Regulation Posts
summary: Unfilled positions threaten to slow implementation of president's agenda. WASHINGTON-The White House's desire to appease both liberal and moderate Democrats has left several top Wall Street regulatory posts unfilled, slowing the implementation of President Biden's agenda nearly a year into the administration.

title: The Movie Line Ben Affleck Tries to Live By
summary: Hint: It's from 'The Shawshank Redemption.' The award-winning director and actor on the piece of advice that changed his life and the one thing that keeps him motivated.. What's the one famous movie line you live by?

title: AmEx Business Travel Going Public Through Merger With Apollo SPAC
summary: Booking services provider is combining with a blank-check company after it made several acquisitions during pandemic. American Express Global Business Travel is merging with a blank-check company backed by Apollo Global Management Inc. to go public with a roughly $5.3 billion valuation, the companies said.

title: Gamer Tyler "Ninja" Blevins Has All-Day Phone Alarms
summary: The 30-year-old is the most-streamed professional gamer in the world-which is why a 10 percent battery really stresses him out. He shares what's on his phone.. Most-recent phone call

title: Total Solar Eclipse 2021: What to Know
summary: A total solar eclipse will sweep across Antarctica on Saturday; other parts of Southern Hemisphere will experience a partial eclipse-if there's a clear view of the horizon. Want to see Saturday's solar eclipse? Book a flight to Antarctica, or take a cruise around the South Orkney Islands, the only places where the sun will be completely darkened on Dec. 4.

title: 2022 Ford Maverick XLT: A Lo-Fi Hybrid Truck With a Nice Price
summary: Starting under $20K, the Maverick packs a lot of practical utility into a compact pickup, writes Dan Neil. BECAUSE NO ONE wanted them around, my people were do-it-yourselfers. Pop made his own machine shop lathe, his own underwater camera housing, his own five-speed transmission. But he wasn't alone. Decades before today's 3-D bakers and candlestick makers, America's postwar dads were doing it for themselves.

title: FDA Aims for Speedy Review of Omicron Vaccines and Drugs
summary: Agency and drugmakers develop testing and manufacturing guidelines in case they are needed for fight against new Covid-19 variant. The Food and Drug Administration is laying the groundwork for the rapid review of Omicron-targeted vaccines and drugs if they turn out to be needed, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: All Pinterest Wants for Christmas Is Users
summary: Pinterest bulls hoping users will come home to the platform for the holidays may be disappointed. Pinterest is trading today at roughly the same price at which it ended the third quarter of last year, when new users were flooding onto the platform. The problem is, lately, those users are leaving.

title: At Block's Base, the Same Square
summary: Changing Square's name to Block might highlight Jack Dorsey's bitcoin bets, but the stock's value rests on much more than that. The renaming of Square to Block, shortly after Jack Dorsey stepped down as Twitter's chief executive, might give investors the sense that Mr. Dorsey's remaining CEO job is now all about bitcoin and blockchain. It isn't.

title: Didi's Drive Home Marks the End of an Era
summary: Didi's flight to Hong Kong isn't unexpected, but the company still faces a tangle of problems. Didi's detour to New York was bumpy and short. Its journey back toward Hong Kong won't be any smoother. But the direction of travel-not only for it, but also for most of its large Chinese peers-is clear. The era of large-scale Chinese listings in the U.S. for any company with remotely sensitive data is over.

title: Want to Fly Private Jets and Not Be 'Flight Shamed?' Try Hailing a Ride
summary: The pandemic has sparked a private-aviation boom, even as concerns about the environmental cost have grown. On-demand services could allow companies and the megarich to have their cake and eat it too.. There is nothing like a pandemic to highlight the advantages of flying private, but "flight shaming" looms large. As big companies and wealthy consumers look to keep flying without the stain of owning planes outright, "Uber-like" services like Wheels Up, VistaJet and Blade could reap the gains.

title: A Couple Stored IRA Gold at Home. They Owe the IRS More Than $300,000.
summary: It can be dangerous to invest retirement-plan funds in esoteric assets without proper guidance. A husband and wife in Rhode Island have learned that lesson the hard way.. It's official: Owners of individual retirement accounts with assets invested in gold and silver coins can't store them in a safe at their home.

title: Companies Cling to Libor as Key Deadline Nears
summary: Banks can't issue new loans using the troubled rate after Dec. 31, so some companies are looking to pull off one last deal before then. U.S. companies need to give up the London interbank offered rate for new debt at the end of December. Many want to close just one more deal before that.

title: Chinese Developers Kaisa, Aoyuan Face Growing Debt Challenges
summary: Kaisa fails to pull off a bond swap, while creditors ask Aoyuan to repay loans after rating downgrades. Two Chinese developers sunk deeper into financial distress, with Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd. failing to pull off a bond swap that would have bought it more time to repay creditors, and lenders calling in loans from China Aoyuan Group Ltd. after credit downgrades.

title: Citigroup Applies for China Securities License
summary: Wall Street bank joins JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs and others in seeking a deeper foothold in the country. Citigroup Inc. has applied for a securities license in China, according to a person familiar with the matter, as the New York-based banking giant eyes a bigger presence in the world's second-largest economy.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.S. to Tighten Rules for Travelers Over Omicron Concerns
summary: President will also extend a mask mandate on airplanes and other public transportation as part of an effort to combat the variant. WASHINGTON-President Biden on Thursday announced plans to tighten up Covid-19 testing timelines for travelers entering the U.S. and extend a mask mandate on airplanes and other public transportation as part of a broad administration effort to combat the Omicron variant.

title: Michigan High-School Shooting Suspect Displayed Warning Signs, Officials Say
summary: Teen's seized journal and video showed 'desire to shoot up a school,' police say. On Monday, the day before accused Oxford High School shooter Ethan Crumbley opened fire on his classmates at the suburban Detroit school, killing four and wounding seven, a teacher had reported that he engaged in "concerning behavior" in a classroom, according to police, prompting school officials to meet with him.

title: Musk's Tesla Share-Selling Spree Tops $10 Billion
summary: The CEO of the electric-vehicle company has unloaded more than 10 million Tesla shares since he started selling last month. Elon Musk has now unloaded more than $10 billion in Tesla Inc. stock as the billionaire's share-selling spree involving his holdings in the electric-vehicle maker stretched into a second month.

title: Senate Approves Spending Bill Averting Government Shutdown
summary: Fight over vaccine rules threatened to slow progress on legislation, which passed House earlier in the day and now goes to Biden. WASHINGTON-Congress passed a short-term extension of government funding and sent the legislation to President Biden's desk, averting a partial shutdown after resolving a standoff over vaccine rules.

title: Bahamas Private Island Ups Its Price to $100 Million
summary: Little Pipe Cay in the Exumas was last listed for $85 million. A Bahamas private island last listed for $85 million in 2018 is back on the market for $100 million.

title: Bridgewater CEO Tells Staff He Is Close to Decision on Senate Run
summary: Hedge-fund chief eyes a crowded Republican field for Pennsylvania seat held by retiring Sen. Pat Toomey. Bridgewater Associates Chief Executive David McCormick told staff Thursday that he was considering resigning to run for U.S. Senate in Pennsylvania, and that he planned to decide within the next few weeks, said people familiar with the matter.

title: Madrid, the City That Wouldn't Lock Down
summary: Isabel Díaz Ayuso called for freedom, kept the regional economy going, and won big at the polls.. Madrid

title: Google Delays Required Office Return for Employees
summary: Tech company will wait until next year to decide when its plan will take effect. Alphabet Inc.'s Google said it is delaying its required return-to-office plans that were scheduled to start Jan. 10 at the earliest for U.S. offices.

title: LeBron James Cleared to Return by NBA After New Round of Covid Tests
summary: After several rounds of conflicting test results, the Los Angeles Lakers star will be back on the court on Friday. Two days after LeBron James was sidelined by the league's health and safety protocols because he registered conflicting Covid-19 results, the NBA's biggest star is back after the league said that subsequent testing determined that he was not a positive case.

title: Lyft Poaches Amazon Executive to Lead Its Finances
summary: The ride-hailing firm's current CFO Brian Roberts is set to step down after the company reached an important profitability milestone. Lyft Inc. poached an Amazon.com Inc. executive to become its next finance chief, a change in the ride-hailing firm's C-suite that comes shortly after the company reached an important profitability milestone.

title: OPEC, Russia Agree to Keep Boosting Oil Output, Jolting Prices
summary: OPEC+ had considered pausing production rises as Omicron fueled concerns about demand and the U.S. released stockpiles. OPEC and a group of Russia-led oil producers agreed to continue pumping more crude, betting that pent-up demand in a post-lockdown world will outweigh any hit to economic activity by the recent permutations of Covid-19.

title: BuzzFeed Suffers Wave of SPAC Investor Withdrawals Before Going Public
summary: Digital-media outlet is raising about $16 million in its public listing; it is also raising $150 million in convertible debt. BuzzFeed Inc. will raise roughly $16 million from its public listing, after the blank-check company it is merging with suffered a wave of investor withdrawals, according to a securities filing and people familiar with the situation.

title: Cuomo Under Federal Investigation Over Sexual-Harassment Allegations
summary: Justice Department opened civil-rights probe into former New York governor's executive chamber in August before he resigned. The Justice Department opened a civil-rights investigation into former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's executive chamber after a state report found that he sexually harassed multiple women, people familiar with the matter said.
